John Arrowwood wrote:

>On 9/2/05, Jeff Haynes <jeff@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>>Not really.  NEAT builds fixed-weight topologies.  A fixed-weight
>>>topology CAN'T learn.  We learn.  Thus, inherently, NEAT and true
>>>intelligence don't go together very well...
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>I guess it all comes down to this and I disagree.  I imagine that when you
>>learn, it is not a topological innovation.  
>>    
>>
>
>Really?  Then how do you propose that learning can take place in a
>fixed topology, fixed weight network?
>  
>
Going back to the discussion about spiking neurons and what info might 
be in the spike trains. One idea I had was that the spike trains convey 
addressing information as well as a value. Consider TCP/IP networks 
where you can address a specific node or you can broadcast to all nodes 
in a sub network. If neurons could do this then in effect you have a 
logical network topology that sits atop of the physical topology. The 
logical topology can then be modified by neurons adjusting which 
addresses they listen too (they could have more than one) and what 
addresses that attach to their outgoing signals.

This is just one example of how such a system might work. The general 
principle I think is that neurons could be describing some kind of 
logical network and that the network can be updated by changes in the 
internal state of neurons (which in biology happens in timescales from 
milliseconds to days) - without any change of connections between 
neurons. Remember the discussion about data buses in the brain? This is 
one approach that would allow data buses to be set up - perhaps like 
dynamic routing tables on the internet.

So it comes down to whether you mean fixed physical topology or fixed 
logical topology.

Colin
